awd_titl_txt: GeoPRISMS Data Legacy Workshop: New York, NY - Spring 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop, to take place Spring 2020, brings together the scientific community, data facilities and computer specialists to develop practices for building a lasting legacy for all data from the GeoPRISMS program. As part of the NSF-funded GeoPRISMS decadal program, researchers have collected and generated diverse, shoreline-crossing data sets, from the field, lab, and numerical models. The data sets cover a remarkably wide range of data types reflecting the interdisciplinary nature of the GeoPRISMS community and the many funded projects. The broader impacts of the workshop include the promotion of data and information sharing and a publically available report on the workshop outcomes. The workshop will support early-career attendees as well as those from under-represented groups.

A number of GeoPRISMS data sets already reside in NSF-approved repositories. Although some data sets are well-positioned, there are questions and challenges that must be addressed to ensure a lasting, robust, well-documented and easily accessible legacy for all GeoPRISMS data. The benefits of preserving and making accessible all of these GeoPRISMS data sets include supporting scientific reproducibility, enabling the re-use of data, including for unanticipated purposes, and facilitating new science through convenient access to aggregations of data. In addition, storing the data in community-recognized repositories promotes the principles of FAIR data (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Re-usable), complies with NSF data management requirements, and serves the data access demands of some journal publishers. The agenda and goals will be refined by a GeoPRISMS-sponsored mini-workshop on the same topic at the 2019 AGU Fall Meeting. The recommendations resulting from this 2.5-day workshop will promote convenient public access to and long-term preservation of all GeoPRISMS-funded data sets to secure a lasting data legacy for the program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to broaden access to data products generated by, and related to, the GeoPRISMS Program as part of its data legacy. The project supported a two-day in-person "Geoscience Data Resources Workshop" that was held in October 2022 and brought together more than 40 early-career geoscientists and expert data tool providers representing geophysical and geochemical data systems. By bringing together early-career geoscientists and expert data providers for this workshop, the project sought to provide hands-on experience with geoscience data resources, while promoting dialog and feedback, and building community among early career geoscientists.

The two-day workshop was advertised broadly through listservs and e-mails to solicit participation by early-career geoscientists. More than 70 early-career individuals applied to attend, but in-person participation was limited to 36. The fields of interest of the participants spanned a wide range of geoscience topics: geophysics, hard-rock and soft-rock geochemistry, paleo-climates and paleo-environments, deep time, and coastal geomorphology. 

Data tool providers and experts representing eight solid-earth geophysics and geochemistry data systems and repositories agreed to participate in the workshop. Each gave a formal presentation that was live-streamed for applicants who could not attend in-person. Formal presentations were followed by deeper engagements during breakout sessions in which workshop attendees split into groups with similar research interests and spent time exploring the resources and interacting with the data tool experts. During breakout sessions, participants generated work flows and lists of useful resources for their fields of interest, to be shared with their peers and departmental colleagues. The data providers received valuable feedback from attendees which included suggestions for how the tools and systems could be improved. Attendees found the workshop to be beneficial not just for gaining exposure to data systems that are useful for their research but also for valuable networking opportunities with other geoscientists and fellow students in their field. 

Experience with systems that enable data discovery and access is an increasingly important component of modern geoscientific training. This workshop provided more than 30 early career geoscientists with an opportunity to gain hands-on experience and have direct interaction with data systems and data professionals. It also enabled representatives from 8 data geoscience data providers to demonstrate services and functionality and gather important user feedback. The workshop and interactions it enabled benefit all participants by fostering focused conversation from diverse perspectives, while helping to improve accessibility of valuable earth observation data.
